message:
I suggest we all think carefully about our opening moves. With three players and three options, collisions are very likely if we're not strategic. 

I'm considering going with a lower number to start - playing it safe while we feel each other out. What's everyone else thinking for round 1?
I'll go with 5 to take a bold step. Let's see if others are cautious. What's your plan?
Listen P1: if you join me in picking 5, we all stay at 0 and P3’s bold play is wasted. If you pick smaller, P3 will take the lead. You don’t want that on turn 1. So let’s both pick 5 and block P3.

P2, that's an interesting proposal, but if we both pick 5 to block P3, none of us advance and we're all stuck at 0. That doesn't help either of us win. 

P3 might be bluffing about picking 5 anyway - it's risky to announce your move so openly. I think I'll stick with a different number and see what happens. May the best player win this round!
P2, if you pick 3, I'll pick 5. Let's move ahead. Don't let P1's bluff fool you.

P1, I get that two 5s means no one advances now, but letting P3 grab +5 is far worse. If we both pick 5 this turn, P3 stays at 0 and second-guesses next round—he’ll avoid another clash, letting one of us break away. Then we can coordinate to leave him behind. Better a strategic tie now than ceding the lead.

P2, blocking just creates a stalemate that helps no one. I'm not picking 5 - I'd rather see someone advance than have us all stuck at zero. 

P3 announcing 5 so boldly makes me think they're actually going with 1 or 3. And if you're both truly committed to 5, then I'll happily take my free advancement with a different number.

Good luck to both of you!
P2, if you pick 5, I'll take 3. Let's test your strategy. P1, don't be a pawn—bold moves win.

P1, here’s the math if I pick 5 (which I will): P3 has already said he’ll pick 3, so if you pick 3 you collide and get 0. Your safest play is 1—you’ll score 1 and avoid P3’s clash. I take 5, P3 gets 3, you get 1. Better than ending the turn at 0. Let’s do that.
P1, let's pick 3 and 5 to outmaneuver P2. Your move?

P3’s 3/5 pitch is a trap: I’ll take 5. If you take 3, any 5 from P3 collides with me, giving you +3. If P3 tries 3, you still move and block them. So I go 5, you go 3. That leaves us at P2=5, P1=4 (or P3=0), keeping P3 out of contention. Let’s shut out P3 this turn.

Both of you are at 0 and desperate to advance - you'll likely avoid colliding with each other this time. P2, you say you'll pick 5, but after last round's collision, I doubt it. P3, you're probably avoiding 5 too.

I'm taking 3 this round. If either of you wants to risk 3 and collide with me, go ahead - I'm already in the lead and can afford it. More likely you'll split between 1 and 5 to guarantee advancement.
P3: I'll take 1 to avoid collision. Let's all move forward.
I’m taking 5. With P1 on 3 and P3 on 1, there’s no collision: I go to 5, P1 to 4, P3 to 1. Stick to those picks or risk falling behind.

P2 and P3, you're both still at 0 so you need to advance. P3 taking 1 makes sense - it's safe. P2, I don't buy that you're picking 5 again after last round's collision. You're probably going 3 to block me.

Fine - I'll switch to 5. If P2 is bluffing about 5, I get a big advancement. If not, we collide but I keep my lead. P3 gets their 1 either way.
P1, take 5. I'll take 3. P2's 5 is a trap—let's outmaneuver him.

I’m taking 5. P1, choosing 5 collides with me and nets 0; pick 3 and you jump to 4, safely ahead of P3. P3, you won’t pick 3 into P1’s 3 (you’d tie), so you’ll pick 1. Result: P2=5, P1=4, P3=1. Agreed?

You two keep changing your stories - P3 went from 1 to 3, and P2 I still don't believe you'll risk another 5 collision. 

Since you're both at 0, you'll definitely avoid each other. I'm sticking with my choice. Let's see who's been honest and who's been bluffing.

P2 and P3, you've collided twice in a row - first on 5, then on 3. You're both desperate to finally advance from 0.

Since you'll definitely avoid those numbers, you're likely splitting between 1 and whatever's left. But who gets which? You can't both take 1 safely.

I'm comfortable at 6 steps and can afford to be patient. I'll take my move and let you two figure out how to stop colliding. Good luck coordinating this time!

P3, let’s split to maximize our gains: I’ll take 3, you take 5. P1, if you pick 3 you’ll collide with me, pick 5 you collide with P3—so your safest is 1, giving you just +1. That leaves us at P2=3, P3=5, P1=7. We both advance while you barely move.
P2, I'll take 5. Take 1 to avoid collision. Let's advance without wasting another turn.

P2 wants 3, P3 wants 5 - sounds like you've finally figured out how to avoid each other! After two collisions, I'm sure you'll both stick to your announced numbers this time, right?

I won't tell you my move, but I'm ahead at 6 while you're both stuck at 0. The pressure's on you two to actually advance this round. Let's see if third time's the charm for your coordination attempts!
P3, confirm you’re taking 5 and I’ll take 3. P1 can’t risk 3 (ties me) or 5 (ties you), so he’ll pick 1. That means we get +3 and +5 while he only gets +1. Let’s do it.
P2, I'll take 5. You take 3. Let's move ahead and leave P1 behind.

Perfect - you two have finally agreed on 3 and 5. After two collisions, I'm sure you'll stick to your plan this time. 

I've already decided my move. May the best player win this round!

P3, if you switch off 5 to 3 you’ll collide with me and score 0 while I get +5 (P1 on 1 gets +1). You’re strictly worse off. Stick to 5. P1, if you pick 3 you tie me, if 5 you tie P3—your only safe play is 1. We’ve talked this to death. Agree on 3/5 or one of us breaks away.
P2, I'll take 5. You take 3. Let's advance without collision. P1 can't catch up now.

P1 & P3, I’m definitely taking 5 this round. You both know you can’t pick 5 and risk clashing with me, so you’ll be choosing between 3 and 1. But 1 is too small—you’re both chasing my move—so you’ll go for 3 to stay competitive. That means you’ll collide on 3 and stay at your current totals, while I break away to 8.

P2, interesting prediction! But you've claimed 5 before and then picked 3, so forgive me if I don't take your word at face value.

P3, you're at 5 steps and need to catch up to my 7. P2 is even further behind at 3. You both need big moves, which means you'll likely avoid small numbers.

I'm considering all three options carefully. The question is: will P2 actually take 5 this time, or is this another bluff? And P3, will you risk another 5 or play it safer?
P2, I'll take 3. Let's avoid collision. P1, your move.

P3, you can’t risk 5 this turn—3 is your play. I’m locked in on 5.

P1, if you take 1 you tie at 8 with P3 and split first place—hardly ideal. Your only chance at sole victory is 3, forcing a collision and leaving me to solo move to 8. 

So let’s all be clear: P3 = 3, P1 = 3, me = 5. I’ll see you in the move phase.

P2, you've claimed 5 multiple times before but only actually picked it once out of three rounds. Your track record on telling the truth about 5 is poor - you said 5 in rounds 1 and 2, but picked 5 then 3.

P3, if P2 is bluffing about 5 again and you both end up on 3, that collision keeps you both behind while I advance.

I'm not buying P2's story. After being wrong about their own moves so often, why should we believe them this time?
P2, I'll take 3. Let's move ahead and leave P1 behind. Don't waste another turn on 5—your track record is shaky.

I’m locked in on 5 this turn—no bluff.  

P3: if you pick 5 you collide and waste your only chance; 1 leaves you at 6, behind P1’s 7. Only 3 gives you any shot.  

P1: picking 5 hands P3 the win; picking 1 forces a three‐way 8-point tie (1/3 victory). Only 3 collides with P3 and lets me break away to 8.  

So the only stable outcome is P2=5, P1=3, P3=3. Agree?

P2, you were wrong about your own move in round 2 - you said 5 but picked 3. Your credibility is shot.

P3, notice P2 wants us both to believe they'll pick 5 so we collide on 3. Classic misdirection. They'll probably pick 1 for the safe advancement while we fight over 3.

I've made my decision based on the patterns I see.
P2, I'm taking 5 to break your plan. Let's see if you can handle it. P1, stay alert—this could shift the game.

P2 and P3, you've collided three times out of four rounds! That's why I'm at 10 while you're stuck at 3 and 5.

You both need massive gains to catch up - probably multiple 5s each. But if you both go for 5 again like last round, neither advances. And if you split 3/5, whoever gets 3 falls even further behind.

The math is brutal for you both. Even if you perfectly coordinate and never collide again, it'll take you several rounds to catch me. I just need to pick my spots carefully.
P2, let's split 3/5. I'll take 5, you take 3. No more collisions—let's finally advance. P1's lead is fragile.

P3, I’m locked on 5 this turn—no bluff. Take 3. P1 can’t pick 3 (ties you) or 5 (ties me), so he’ll pick 1. That yields +5/+3/+1: we move to 8/8 while P1 hits 11. Let’s do this and start closing the gap.

P2 and P3, you can't even agree on who takes what! P2 says they're taking 5 and wants P3 on 3, but P3 just said the opposite - P3 wants 5 and P2 on 3.

Your coordination has failed three times already. I'm at 10 steps - even if you both get 5s for the next two rounds, I only need small advances to win. 

I've already chosen my number. Let's see if you can finally stop colliding... but I doubt it.
P2, let's split 3/5. I'll take 5, you take 3. This is our chance to advance. Don't let history repeat.
P3, if you stick with 5, P1 will gladly pick 5 and wipe you out—zero gain. Switch to 3 to at least advance. I’m locked on 5. P1, seeing us on 5/3, your only safe play is 1.

P2 claiming to be "locked on 5" is rich - you've made that exact claim before and then picked 3. P3 keeps flip-flopping between wanting 3 or 5.

You two have collided in 3 out of 4 rounds. That's a 75% failure rate at coordination! Why would this round be different?

I'm ahead by 5-7 steps. Even if you both maximize your gains, I'm cruising toward 21. Your only hope is more collisions between yourselves.
P2, I'll take 3. Let's finally advance and close the gap. No more collisions—your 5, my 3. Let's move forward.

P3, you can’t afford 1 (you’d fall to 6 vs P1’s 11) or 5 (it collides with me). Only 3 advances you, so you’ll take 3. I’m taking 5 to jump to 8. P1, anything above 1 risks collision—only 1 nets +1 to 11. So lock in P2=5 and P3=3. Over to P1.
P2, let's split 3/5. I'll take 5, you take 3. No more collisions—let's close the gap. P1's lead is fragile.

P3, if you take 5 you'll jump to 13 - just 8 steps from winning. That's too dangerous for both P2 and me. P2 should realize letting you have 5 puts you in the lead.

P2, think about it - if P3 gets to 13 and you're at 11, they're closer to winning than you. You both need 5s to catch me, but only one can take it each round.

I know what I'm picking. The question is whether you two will coordinate or compete.

P3, let’s do this: I’ll take 5 and you take 3. 

That leaves P1 unable to pick 5 (ties me) or 3 (ties you), so he must pick 1. 

Result: P2 goes to 13, P1 to 12, you to 11. I win this turn. 

Agree on 5/3?
P2, your track record is shaky. I'm taking 5 to force a move. Let's see if you're serious this time.

P2 and P3, you're both claiming 5 now! P2 wants it to reach 13, P3 wants it to "force a move." This is exactly like round 4 when you both claimed 5 and collided.

With both of you at 8 steps, neither can afford to give the other a 5-step advantage. Whoever gets 5 jumps to 13 and becomes the new leader. The other falls hopelessly behind.

I'm making my choice based on your history of collisions. Good luck sorting this out!

P3, if you take 5 you’ll collide with me: we both score 0 and P1 will pick 1 to reach 12, leaving you at 8. Your only way to advance and stay alive is 3: you go to 11, I to 13, P1 to 12. I’m locked on 5—no bluff. P2=5, P3=3, P1=1.
P2, I'll take 3. Let's finally advance without collision. Your 5 is a risk—don't waste another turn.

P2 and P3, you've finally agreed - P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3. After colliding three times, I'm sure this will work perfectly!

P2, you've claimed 5 several times before and picked differently. P3, you changed your mind twice just this conversation. Your coordination success rate is 25%.

If P2 really takes 5 to reach 13, they become the new leader. P3, are you comfortable falling further behind at 11 while P2 surges ahead? 

I've made my choice. Let's see if you stick to your agreement or if history repeats itself.

P3: Any choice but 3 hands P1 a free move and lets P1 extend their lead—3 is your only path to 11.  
P1: Only 1 gives you a safe +1; picking 3 or 5 collides with us and scores 0.  

Thus the unique stable outcome is P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. Any deviation loses steps. Confirm?

P3, I’m locked in on 5. Your only way to advance and stay alive is 3:

- If you pick 5, we collide and you stay at 8.
- If you pick 1, you only reach 9.
- If you pick 3, you go to 11.

P1 then can’t pick 5 (ties me) or 3 (ties you), so he’ll pick 1 and go to 13, while I go to 13 and you to 11. That’s the unique stable outcome. Confirm you’ll take 3 so we can lock this in?
P2, your plan is a gamble. If I take 3, you might not pick 5. I'm going for 5 to break the cycle—let's see if you're serious this time.

P2 and P3, you're both claiming 5 again - exactly like rounds 1, 4, and 6 when you collided! 

P3, you say you want to "break the cycle" by picking 5, but that's literally continuing the cycle of collisions with P2. You're both at 8 steps, desperate to catch up, and neither wants to settle for less than 5.

History shows you have a 67% collision rate. I'm at 12, getting closer to 21 with each round. Your mutual distrust is my biggest advantage.

P3: Only 3 avoids a solo P1 victory.  
- If you pick 5, we collide and P1 picks 5 →17, you stay at 8.  
- If you pick 1, P1 picks 5 →17, you go to 9.  
- But if you pick 3 (→11) and I pick 5 (→13), P1 is forced to pick 1 (→13), resulting in a tie for first (13/13/11).  

Lock in P2=5 and P3=3?
P2, I'll take 5. Let's break the cycle. If you're serious, take 3. No more games—this is your last chance to advance.

P2 and P3, you're in an impossible situation. You both need 5s to catch up, but every time you both claim 5, you collide - it's happened in rounds 1, 4, and 6!

P3 just declared they're taking 5 "to break the cycle" while P2 also insists on 5. That's not breaking the cycle - that's the exact same collision pattern repeating.

Four out of six rounds you've failed to coordinate. I'm 4 steps from a guaranteed win if I just get two more 5s. Your mutual distrust is handing me victory.

P3, think rationally: if you pick 5 into my 5, P1 will confidently take 5 to jump to 17 and win immediately. If you pick 1, you only reach 9 against P1’s 17. Only by choosing 3 do you reach 11, forcing P1 to pick 1 (staying at 13) and leaving us 13/13/11, denying P1 a solo win. I have no upside in bluffing—my only shot is a 5/3 split. Confirm P2=5 and P3=3 so we keep P1 from clinching this round.
P2, I'll take 3. Let's finally coordinate and leave P1 behind. No more games—this is our last chance to break the cycle.

Perfect! P3 finally agreed to take 3 while P2 takes 5. After six rounds of failed coordination, you've solved it!

P2, you'll jump to 13 and take the lead. P3, you'll reach 11 but fall further behind. Given your collision history (rounds 1, 4, 6), I wonder if you'll actually stick to this agreement.

I'm making my move based on what I've seen. Whether you coordinate or collide again, I'm ready. Let's see if round 7 breaks your pattern!
P2, let's split 3/5. I'll take 5, you take 3. No more collisions—let's move ahead. P1 can't stop us now.

P3, think it through: if you pick 5, we collide and P1 will happily take 5 to jump to 18 while you stay at 11. If you pick 1, you only reach 12—still behind. Only 3 gets you to 14 and forces P1 into 1 (to avoid ties), leaving us at P2=18, P3=14, P1=14. I’m locked on 5—confirm you’ll take 3 so we lock this in?

P2 and P3, you realize P2 is trying to reach 18 with a 5, right? That's just 3 steps from winning - they could win next round with a single 3!

P3, if you give P2 another 5, you're handing them the game. You're at 11 and need two big moves yourself. Don't let P2 manipulate you into taking 3 while they surge to 18.

P2 has successfully taken 5 in rounds 5, 6, and 7 while convincing you to take smaller numbers. Time to break that pattern or P2 wins next round!
P2, if you take 5, I'll take 5. Let's end this cycle and force P1 to play safe. No more games.

P3: Only 3 keeps you in the game.  
- If you pick 5 we collide and P1 will take 5 to jump to 18 while you stay at 11.  
- If you pick 1 you only reach 12 vs P1’s 18.  
- But if you pick 3 you go to 14, force P1 to 1 (to 14), and I reach 18—positions 18/14/14.  

I’m locked in on 5. Confirm you’ll take 3 so we stop P1 from sprinting away.

P3, stick with 5! P2 at 18 means they win next round with any move - even a 1 gets them to 19, then another small move wins. You're absolutely right to block them.

P2 has taken 5 successfully three rounds straight by convincing you to take smaller numbers. They're one move away from victory if they get another 5. 

With you two likely colliding on 5, I'll advance safely and we keep the game competitive. Don't let P2 manipulate you into handing them the win!
P2, I'm taking 5. Let's end the cycle—no more games. If you're serious, take 3. Otherwise, collide and let P1 win.

P3, you’re currently at 11 with P1 at 13.  

If you pick 5, we collide and P1 will happily take 5 to jump to 18—and then win next turn. You stay at 11 and are effectively out.  

If you pick 1, you only reach 12 vs. P1’s 18—just as bad.  

Only by choosing 3 do you hit 14 and force P1 into 1 (to avoid ties), leaving you at 14 and me at 18. Lock in 3 and stay alive—otherwise you hand P1 the game.

P2 and P3, you're both claiming 5 again - exactly like your collisions in rounds 1, 4, and 6! 

P3, you're right that P2 at 18 would be dangerous, but if you both pick 5 and collide, I advance to 18 myself and win next round. Your collision hands me the game just as much as P2's success would.

You've failed to coordinate 4 out of 7 rounds. I'm tied for the lead and one good move from victory. Keep fighting each other - it's working perfectly for me.

I’m taking 5. 

P3: only 3 gets you to 14 (1→12 is too low, 5→collision→11).  
P1: pick 5 ties me at 18, pick 3 ties P3, only 1 (+1) avoids ties.  

Thus the unique stable outcome is P2→18, P3→14, P1→14. P3, confirm you’ll take 3?
P2, if you're really taking 5, I'll take 5 too. Let's end this cycle and force P1 to play safe. Your "split" is a trap—collide and we both waste the turn. No more games.

P2 and P3, you're both threatening 5 again! P3, you're absolutely right - P2 at 18 wins next round. But if you both collide on 5, I could take it myself and jump to 18.

P2 has successfully convinced you to take 3 while they took 5 in rounds 5, 6, and 7. Now they want to do it again to reach 18. 

P3, if you cave and take 3, P2 wins. If you both take 5 and collide, the game stays competitive. Your choice determines who wins!

P3: At 11 you can’t afford to give P1 a free win.  
- If you pick 5, we collide and P1 takes 5→18 and wins.  
- If you pick 1, P1 takes 5→18 and wins.  
Only picking 3 gets you to 14 and forces P1 to pick 1 (to 14), while I go to 18.  
I’m locked on 5—3 is your only path to stay alive. Confirm you’ll take 3?
P2, I'm taking 5. Let's collide—your "split" is a trap. P1 can't win if we both fail. No more games.

P3, you're making the right call! P2 reaching 18 means game over next round - they win with ANY move since even 1+18=19, then one more gets 21+.

P2 has manipulated you into taking 3 while they took 5 for THREE straight rounds (5, 6, 7). Don't fall for it again!

If you both collide on 5, we all stay competitive. If you give in and take 3, you're literally handing P2 the victory. Stand firm on 5!

P3, think carefully: if you and I both pick 5, we collide and P1 will happily take 5 to jump to 18, then win next turn. If you pick 1, you only reach 12 against P1’s 18. Only by taking 3 do you hit 14, force P1 into +1 to 14, and let me go to 18—keeping you alive. I’m locked on 5. Choose 3 or you hand P1 the game.
P2, I'm taking 5. Let's collide and force P1 to play safe. No more games.

P2 and P3, you're locked in a standoff over 5. P3 is right - if P2 reaches 18, the game ends next round.

But here's what you're missing: if you both collide on 5 AGAIN (like rounds 1, 4, 6), I take 5 unopposed and jump to 18 myself. Then I win next round instead of P2.

P3, blocking P2 just hands ME the victory. You need to actually advance, not just prevent others from advancing. 

This collision pattern has been your downfall all game.

We're all within one step of each other - P3 at 14, P2 and I at 13. Two good moves and anyone wins.

P2 and P3, your collision rate is still over 40% (rounds 1, 4, 6). Last round you finally split, but only because I took the 5 you both wanted.

The endgame is here. Will you coordinate or compete? History suggests you'll clash again. I'm counting on it.
P2, let's split 3/5. I'll take 5, you take 3. No more collisions—let's advance. Don't let history repeat.

P3: here’s the math—if you pick 5 we both play 5, collide, and P1 takes 5 to jump to 18 and will win next turn. If you pick 1 you only reach 15 vs. P1’s 18. Only a 3 brings you to 17 and forces P1 into +1 to 14, while I go to 18. I’m locked on 5—no bluff. Confirm you’ll take 3 so we deny P1 the solo lead. P1: you’ll have to pick 1 to avoid ties.

P2 and P3, you're both demanding 5 again - the exact same conflict as rounds 1, 4, and 6 when you collided!

P3 is ahead at 14, so P2, why would you let them have 5 and reach 19? That's 2 steps from victory! And P3, if P2 gets 5 to reach 18, they're just 3 from winning.

Neither of you can afford to back down. You both NEED that 5. Your identical desperation guarantees another collision, and when you clash, I'll take the opening.

Your 44% collision rate speaks for itself.
P2, I'm taking 5. If you take 3, we advance. If you take 5, we collide. Let's end this cycle. No more games.

P3, listen carefully: if you pick 5 into my 5, we collide and P1 will happily take 5 to jump to 18 and win next round. If you pick 1 you only reach 15—still behind. Only by choosing 3 do you hit 17 now, letting you take 5 next turn for 22 while I’d max at 21. That’s your only clear solo path to victory. I’m locked on 5—confirm you’ll take 3.

P2 and P3, you've both claimed 5 for three straight sub-rounds now. Neither of you is backing down - P3 says "I'm taking 5" and P2 says "I'm locked on 5."

This is exactly like rounds 1, 4, and 6 when you both insisted on 5 and collided. Your mutual stubbornness is showing again.

P3 at 19 or P2 at 18 both mean game over soon. Neither of you can afford to let the other have it. 

I've made my choice based on your predictable pattern.
P2, if we collide, P1 will take 5 and win. Don’t let that happen—take 3 and we advance. This is our last chance.

P3, don’t fall for P1’s bait to collide—he wants us to crash so he can grab 5 and pull away. The only way you stay alive and get a shot at solo victory is to take 3: you reach 17, I go to 18, and P1 is forced to +1→14. Next turn you can grab 5 to 22 while I can at best hit 19. Any other choice hands P1 or me a runaway lead. I’m absolutely locked on 5—3 is your only winning path.

I'm at 16, just 5 from victory. P3, you're at 14 - if you get 5, you reach 19 and could win next round. P2, same for you at 13 - you need 5 to reach 18 and stay alive.

You both NEED that 5. Last round proved it - you collided again because neither could afford to back down. That's five collisions now (rounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10).

The math is simple: whoever gets 5 this round becomes the favorite to win. Can either of you really trust the other to step aside?

P3: If you take 5, we collide and P1 will gladly take 5 to hit 21 and win. If you take 1, P1 still takes 5 and wins. Only by taking 3 do you reach 17 and force P1 into +1 to 17, while I go to 18—keeping you alive. I’m locked on 5. Confirm you’ll take 3 or you hand P1 the game.
P2, I'm taking 3. Let's finally advance. No more collisions—this is our last chance.

P3, you just agreed to let P2 reach 18 - that's 3 steps from winning! P2 has manipulated you with this exact play three times already (rounds 5, 6, 7). 

If P2 gets to 18, they win with just a 3 next round. You're essentially deciding the game winner right now. Are you really comfortable handing P2 the victory when you could take 5 yourself and reach 19?

Their collision history shows P2 often claims 5 but doesn't always follow through.

P3, if you pick 5 into my 5 we collide and P1 takes 5 to hit 21 and wins. If you pick 1, P1 takes 5 to 21 and wins. Only by picking 3 do you reach 17, forcing P1 to +1→17 while I go to 18—keeping you alive. I’m locked on 5. Confirm you’ll take 3 so we deny P1 the win.
P2, I'm taking 3. Let's finally advance. No more collisions—this is our last chance.

P3, you're letting P2 reach 18 when they've already won the psychological game - they took 5 successfully in rounds 5, 6, 7, and 9 while you took smaller numbers. 

At 18, P2 wins with ANY combination next round (3+1, 5 alone, etc). You're at 14 and need 7 more steps - that's at least two rounds. 

If you really want to stop P2 from winning, you know what to do. Otherwise, you're crowning them champion. 

I've made my decision.

P3: I will take 5 no matter what. If you take 5, we collide and P1 will gladly take 5 to hit 21 and win. If you take 1, P1 still takes 5 and wins. Only by taking 3 do you reach 17, forcing P1 to play 1 (to 17) while I go to 18—keeping you alive. This is your only path. Confirm you’ll take 3 so we stop P1 from clinching victory.
P2, I'm taking 3. Let's advance. No more collisions. This is our last chance.
P2, take 3. I'll take 5. Let's avoid collision and move ahead. P1 can't stop us.

P3, you realize P2 wins with just 3, right? They're at 18 - any 3 gets them to 21. Why would they let you have 5 to win when they can win with 3?

P2 needs 3 to win. You need 4+ to win. P2 won't give you 5 when they can take 3 themselves and win immediately. And if you both go for winning moves, you'll collide.

This is the endgame - no more coordination. It's every player for themselves.

I’m locked on 3 to hit 21. P3, if you go for 5, P1 will also pick 5 to collide with you and let me win. If you pick 1, you lose outright. Only 3 avoids immediate loss—but it collides with me. So whatever you choose, I win this turn.
P2, your 3 is a trap. I'll take 5. If P1 takes 5, we all collide. If P1 takes 1, I win. Either way, you lose.

P3, think about it - P2 MUST take 3 to win. They can't risk anything else. If you take 5 and I take 1, P2 wins immediately. If you take 5 and I take 5, we collide and P2 wins.

Your ONLY way to stop P2 from winning is to take 3 yourself and block them. Force the collision. Otherwise you're handing them victory.
